Detailed Description

The one and only source file for codeform.

This source file compiles without warnings with GCC 2.95.2 and 3.3.3:
$ gcc -W -Wall -ansi -pedantic -O2 -g -o codeform codeform.c

Definition in file codeform.c.

void add_parts (  struct strings_t *  data,
const struct strings_t *  prev,
const char *  str
) 
 

Separates the parts of the rule str and adds them to data, which is a structure containing an array of strings. If a part is "*", it is assigned the value of the same section of the previous rule (determined from prev).

Parameters:
data The structure to add the parts of the rule str to.
prev The structure containing the parts of the previous rule (or NULL if this is the first rule).
str The string representing the current rule, with all its parts.

Definition at line 1133 of file codeform.c.

Referenced by add_rule().

void add_rule (  struct rules_t *  rules,
char *  str,
const char *  file,
int  line
) 
 

Adds the rule str to the structure rules containing the array of rules. In doing so, it separates the parts of the rule, extracts variables and processes escapes; and does a search on the existing rules to find the position of the current one. If the rule is a header it is handled, too.

Parameters:
rules The structure containing the rules parsed so far, to add the latest rule str to.
str The string representing the rule to add to rules.
file The file that the rule str came from.
line The line of the file that the rule str came from.

) 
 

Adds the rule one to the correct place, keeping the list of rules sorted.

Parameters:

rsort The index to sort this rule by.
one The rule to add to rd.
Returns:
Same as find_rule_new(): 1 if an exact match was found, 0 otherwise. 2 if one is already an existing rule.

int add_rule_type (  struct rules_t *  rules,
enum type_t *  t,
char **  str,
const char *  file,
int  line
) 
 

Called by add_rule() to determine the type of the rule str.

Parameters:
rules The array of rules that have been parsed so far.
t The pointer to store the type of the current rule.
str The rule itself.
file The file which the rule str came from.
line The line of the file from which the rule came.
Returns:
0 if no errors occured and str is an ordinary rule; nonzero if the rule is a header, an invalid header, or not under a header. If str is an inline header, positions str past the header and returns 0 so that str may be treated as an ordinary rule.

void add_string_copy (  struct strings_t *  data,
const struct strings_t *  prev
) 
 

Adds a string to data, the equivalent string in prev. The string itself isn't copied, the pointer is just set to the same position in (dynamically-allocated) memory.

Parameters:
data The strings_t structure to add a string to.
prev The structure to get the pointer to the string from.

void append_rulelist (  const char *  from,
const char *  to,
struct rulelist_t *  list,
FILE *  out
) 
 

Starts a tag, ignoring tags of the same kind in sequence. That is, if two keywords with the same precede-with occur in a row, don't close the tag only to start it again.

Parameters:
from The text to print before (now) if the previous tag wasn't the same as it.
to The text to print after if from doesn't match list->from.
list The structure containing the previous tag.
out The output file stream to write everything to.

int check_parts (  int  rparts,
int  xparts,
const char *  str
) 
 

Checks to see if the number of parts in the rule str has at least rparts (required parts) with an optional up to xparts extra parts.

Parameters:
rparts Minimum number of required parts for the rule str to have.
xparts Optional number of extra parts in addition to rparts.
str The string to check the parts of.
Returns:
True if the number of parts is in the range rparts to rparts+xparts.

void chomp_newline (  char *  str,
size_t *  flen
) 
 

Removes the newline characters, if any, off of the end of str. flen is adjusted accordingly. (Newline characters are '\n' and '\r', to support CRLF newlines under UNIX systems.)

Parameters:
str The string to remove newline characters from the end of.
flen The length of the string str, decreased with each character removed.

int find_rule_match (  const struct rules_t *  rules,
const char *  p,
size_t *  pos
) 
 

Executes a binary search for p in the existing rules in rt. The longest match is assigned to pos.

Parameters:
rules The array of existing rules to search through.
p The string to search through the rules for.
pos The variable to set to the longest match found, if any; if none, set to (size_t)-1.
Returns:
1 if an exact match was found, 0 otherwise.

int find_rule_new (  const struct rules_t *  rules,
const char *  p,
size_t *  pos
) 
 

Binary searches through the existing rules in rt for the position that the rule p should be in, putting the result in pos.

Parameters:
rules The structure containing the array of existing rules.
p The new rule to search for.
pos The variable to store the position found in. Set to (size_t)-1 if no match was found.
Returns:
1 if an exact match (to the shortest length) was found, 0 otherwise. 2 if an exact match the whole way was found.

Returns:

size_t *  len
)
